G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A.proposition: This action is brought in the Cambridge District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and G.L. c. 185C, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court and the claims arise out of a residential tenancy in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C.proposition: This action is brought in the Cambridge District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and G.L. c. 185C, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court and the claims arise out of a residential tenancy in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue in this Court is proper because the Property is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Cambridge.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Venue in this Court is proper because the Property is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Cambridge.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease and tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and landlords are also subject to the statutory covenant set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease and tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and landlords are also subject to the statutory covenant set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes and applies an implied covenant (warranty) of quiet enjoyment in a residential lease, and treats constructive eviction as flowing from its breach. However, in the excerpt provided, the court does not expressly say that every residential tenancy-at-will and lease includes such an implied covenant, nor does it mention G.L. c. 186, § 14 or describe the statutory covenant. The case thus supports the existence and enforceability of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law, but not explicitly the universality to all residential tenancies or the statutory overlay.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease and tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and landlords are also subject to the statutory covenant set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly discusses the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and G.L. c. 186, § 14, and applies § 14 to the landlord, but it does not state that the covenant is implied in *every* residential lease and tenancy‑at‑will. Nor does it expressly say that all landlords in all such arrangements are subject to the statutory covenant; it assumes applicability on these facts and analyzes breach. Thus, while consistent with the proposition, the case does not itself clearly articulate the universal rule claimed.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from 'serious' interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14; Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); Ianello v. Court Mgmt. Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323-324 (1987). A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its 'acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.' Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994)."

General Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 provides in relevant part that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that a landlord who does so shall be liable for actual and statutory damages.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to the “freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy—acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises.” Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994) (quoting Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–16 (1977)).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment in the same terms as the proposition, stating that it protects the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the tenancy and acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. The court cites its own prior cases for this formulation and then applies that standard to the facts, so the case squarely supports the quoted legal principle.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880, 884 (1988). Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987). Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 167 (1985). Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102.” (Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).)

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial, recurring noise and other disturbances, when attributable to a landlord’s acts or omissions, may amount to an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard of fault (at least negligence) required for a landlord’s liability under the Massachusetts quiet enjoyment statute and cites other cases where physical defects and failures to repair interfered with quiet enjoyment. It does not address noise, recurring disturbances, or similar nuisance-type conditions as interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about substantial, recurring noise and disturbances attributable to a landlord’s acts or omissions.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–77 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Landlords may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment when they fail to take reasonable steps to prevent or remedy conditions that substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment, even where the underlying activity is otherwise lawful.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that the tenant had a valid quiet enjoyment claim, but it does not discuss the legal standards for landlord liability for quiet enjoyment or address situations where the underlying activity is otherwise lawful. The holding and reasoning focus almost entirely on the proper measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in the context of Section 8 subsidies, not on the scope of a landlord’s duty to prevent or remedy substantial interferences. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Landlords may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment when they fail to take reasonable steps to prevent or remedy conditions that substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment, even where the underlying activity is otherwise lawful.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the covenant of quiet enjoyment to impose liability where the landlord’s conduct (including omissions) has the natural and probable consequence of substantially interfering with the tenant’s use of the premises, and it expressly rejects a requirement of malicious or specific intent. It holds Gem liable under § 14 for allowing repeated flooding caused in part by third-party actions, emphasizing the landlord’s duty to prevent unsanitary, non‑watertight conditions rather than illegality of the underlying activity. This squarely supports liability for failure to take reasonable steps to prevent or remedy conditions that interfere with quiet enjoyment, independent of whether the underlying cause is otherwise lawful.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights…. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The infiltration of construction dust and debris into Plaintiff’s unit through vents and other openings has further impaired Plaintiff’s comfort, health, and use of the Premises, exacerbating the interference with quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 9.proposition: To the extent the Court finds that the interference was willful or knowing, or that Defendant unreasonably failed to abate the conditions after notice, enhanced or statutory damages are appropriate under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related authorities.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: An award of prejudgment and postjudgment interest as allowed by law, including under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
